MATH_001.name: Set
description: A set is a well-defined collection of distinct objects, known as elements.
Sets are usually denoted by capital letters with elements inside curly braces, e.g., \( A = \{a, b, c\} \).
The order of elements does not matter, and duplicate elements are ignored.
MATH_001.notes: Think of a set as a bag of unique items. It's the fundamental building block for nearly all of mathematics! üß±
references: Halmos, P. R. (1960). Naive Set Theory

MATH_002.name: Subset
description: A set \(A\) is a subset of a set \(B\) if every element of \(A\) is also an element of \(B\).
This relationship is denoted as \(A \subseteq B\).
Every set is a subset of itself.
MATH_002.notes: If set B contains all the items of set A (and possibly more), then A is a subset of B. Easy peasy!

MATH_003.name: Empty Set
description: The empty set is the unique set that contains no elements.
It is denoted by \(\emptyset\) or \(\{\}\).
The empty set is a subset of every set.
MATH_003.notes: It might seem strange, but the concept of 'nothing' is incredibly important for defining everything else.

MATH_004.name: Cartesian Product
description: The Cartesian product of two sets \(A\) and \(B\) is the set of all ordered pairs \((a, b)\) where \(a \in A\) and \(b \in B\).
It is denoted by \(A \times B\).
This concept extends to more than two sets, forming n-tuples.
MATH_004.notes: If you have a set of shirts and a set of pants, the Cartesian product is all possible outfits! üëïüëñ

MATH_005.name: Power Set
description: The power set of a set \(S\) is the set of all possible subsets of \(S\), including the empty set and \(S\) itself.
It is denoted by \(P(S)\) or \(2^S\).
If \(S\) has \(n\) elements, its power set \(P(S)\) has \(2^n\) elements.
MATH_005.notes: The power set reveals the complete substructure of a set. It's a 'set of sets'!

MATH_006.name: Mapping (Function)
description: A mapping (or function) \(f\) from a set \(A\) to a set \(B\) is a rule that assigns to each element \(x \in A\) exactly one element \(y \in B\).
\(A\) is called the domain, and \(B\) is the codomain.
This is denoted as \(f: A \to B\).
MATH_006.notes: Mappings are the action heroes of math, describing relationships and transformations between sets. ‚öôÔ∏è

MATH_007.name: Injective Mapping
description: An injective (or one-to-one) mapping ensures that no two elements in the domain map to the same element in the codomain.
Think of it as a 'no sharing outputs' rule.
MATH_007.notes: Injective functions preserve distinctness. They don't merge or lose information.

MATH_008.name: Surjective Mapping
description: A surjective (or onto) mapping ensures that every element in the codomain \(B\) has at least one corresponding element in the domain \(A\).
The range of the function is equal to its codomain.
Think of it as 'covering all the targets'.
MATH_008.notes: Surjective functions hit every possible output value. Nothing in the codomain is left out.

MATH_009.name: Bijective Mapping
description: A bijective mapping is both injective and surjective.
It creates a perfect one-to-one correspondence between the elements of the domain and the codomain.
Bijective functions have a unique inverse function.
MATH_009.notes: Bijections are the gold standard of mappings, showing that two sets are structurally identical in size. ü§ù

MATH_010.name: Category
description: A category is a collection of 'objects' and 'morphisms' (arrows) between them.
It includes an associative composition of morphisms and an identity morphism for each object.
Category theory is a high-level abstraction that studies mathematical structures and their relationships.
MATH_010.notes: This is math about math! It unifies concepts from different fields by focusing on structure and transformations. üåå
references: Mac Lane, S. (1998). Categories for the Working Mathematician

MATH_011.name: Isomorphism
description: In category theory, an isomorphism is a morphism \(f: A \to B\) that has a two-sided inverse \(g: B \to A\).
This means \(f \circ g = 1_B\) and \(g \circ f = 1_A\).
Isomorphic objects are structurally identical from the perspective of the category.
MATH_011.notes: This is the categorical generalization of a bijection. It's the ultimate 'sameness' detector.

MATH_012.name: Monomorphism
description: A monomorphism (or mono) is the categorical generalization of an injective mapping.
It is a 'left-cancelable' morphism: if \(f \circ g_1 = f \circ g_2\), then \(g_1 = g_2\).
In the category of sets, monomorphisms are exactly the injective functions.
MATH_012.notes: While it feels like injectivity, this definition works in contexts where 'elements' don't exist!

MATH_013.name: Epimorphism
description: An epimorphism (or epi) is the categorical generalization of a surjective mapping.
It is a 'right-cancelable' morphism: if \(g_1 \circ f = g_2 \circ f\), then \(g_1 = g_2\).
In the category of sets, epimorphisms are exactly the surjective functions.
MATH_013.notes: Beware! In some categories (like Rings), an epimorphism is not always surjective. Abstraction is tricky!

MATH_014.name: Functor
description: A functor is a mapping between categories.
It maps objects to objects and morphisms to morphisms in a way that preserves composition and identity.
Functors are the 'morphisms' of categories, allowing us to compare them.
MATH_014.notes: If categories are worlds of mathematical structures, functors are the portals between them. ‚ú®

MATH_015.name: Number Theory
description: Number theory is a branch of pure mathematics devoted primarily to the study of the integers and integer-valued functions.
It explores properties like divisibility, prime numbers, and solutions to equations in integers.
MATH_015.notes: The 'Queen of Mathematics'! It's full of simple-to-state problems that are incredibly hard to solve.
references: Hardy, G. H., & Wright, E. M. (1938). An Introduction to the Theory of Numbers

MATH_016.name: Rational & Irrational Numbers
description: A rational number can be expressed as a fraction \(p/q\) of two integers, where \(q \neq 0\).
An irrational number cannot be expressed as such a fraction. Its decimal representation never terminates and never repeats.
Examples of irrationals include \(\sqrt{2}\), \(\pi\), and \(e\).
MATH_016.notes: The discovery of irrational numbers was a major shock to the ancient Greeks, who believed all numbers were rational!

MATH_017.name: Proof by Contradiction
description: A method of indirect proof where one assumes the opposite of what they want to prove.
You then follow a series of logical steps until you arrive at a logically impossible conclusion (a contradiction).
This proves that the initial assumption must have been false.
MATH_017.notes: A powerful and sometimes sneaky way to prove something is true by showing its opposite is absurd. üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

MATH_018.name: Pythagorean Theorem
description: In a right-angled triangle, the square of the length of the hypotenuse (the side opposite the right angle) is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides.
The formula is \(a^2 + b^2 = c^2\).
MATH_018.notes: One of the most famous and useful theorems in all of geometry!

MATH_EX_001.name: Irrationality of sqrt(2) + sqrt(3)
MATH_EX_001.description: This exercise tests your ability to combine algebraic manipulation with a proof by contradiction.
MATH_EX_001.hints: Assume the expression equals a rational number 'r'. Square both sides and try to isolate a single square root term.
MATH_EX_001.result: Assume \(\sqrt{2} + \sqrt{3} = r\) (rational). Squaring gives \(5 + 2\sqrt{6} = r^2\), which means \(\sqrt{6} = (r^2 - 5)/2\). Since r is rational, the right side is rational, implying \(\sqrt{6}\) is rational. This is a known contradiction. Thus, the original assumption is false.

MATH_EX_002.name: Irrationality of log_2(3)
MATH_EX_002.description: This classic proof uses the definition of logarithms and the fundamental theorem of arithmetic.
MATH_EX_002.hints: Assume \(\log_2 3 = p/q\). Rewrite this in exponential form and look for a contradiction related to prime factors.
MATH_EX_002.result: Assume \(\log_2 3 = p/q\). This means \(2^{p/q} = 3\), so \(2^p = 3^q\). By the unique prime factorization theorem, an integer power of 2 cannot equal an integer power of 3 (unless both exponents are 0, which is not the case). This is a contradiction.

MATH_EX_003.name: Proof of Pythagorean Theorem
MATH_EX_003.statement: Prove the Pythagorean theorem: \(a^2 + b^2 = c^2\).
MATH_EX_003.description: This exercise requires a geometric proof to demonstrate the famous relationship in a right-angled triangle.
MATH_EX_003.hints: Consider a large square with side length (a+b). Arrange four copies of the triangle inside it. What shape is left in the middle?
MATH_EX_003.result: Arrange four right triangles (sides a, b, c) inside a square of side (a+b). The total area is \((a+b)^2\). The area is also the sum of the four triangles \(4 \times \frac{1}{2}ab\) plus the area of the inner square, \(c^2\). Equating them: \(a^2 + 2ab + b^2 = 2ab + c^2\), which simplifies to \(a^2 + b^2 = c^2\).
